medical_history.chief_complaint: Progressive edema of the legs, abdominal distention, and pain.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient's symptoms began approximately 10 months before evaluation with episodes of pain and swelling in the feet and ankles, initially occurring in the evening after prolonged standing. These episodes became more frequent and began to occur earlier in the day, progressing to involve the lower legs and thighs. Four weeks before evaluation, leg swelling worsened and abdominal distention developed, along with intermittent swelling of the hands and periorbital swelling in the morning. One week before evaluation, diffuse abdominal pain and nausea developed.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Hypothyroidism, latent tuberculosis, previous negative chest radiograph, two spontaneous vaginal deliveries, ectopic pregnancy, ovary-sparing abdominal hysterectomy for fibroid uterus, and appendectomy.
medical_history.social_history: The patient grew up on a Caribbean island and immigrated to the United States at age 19. She works as an assistant in a healthcare facility and lives with her husband and two healthy children. There is no history of alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drug use.
